div.head: Names and Dates
div.p: This chapter describes a module which may be used for the encoding of names (names of persons or corporations/organizations) or descriptive phrases for styles, periods or geographical indications. In section xy Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses it was noted that the elements provided in the core module alow an encoder to specify that a given text segment is a proper noun, or a referring string. The elements provided by the present module allow the encoder to supply a detailed sub-structure for such referring strings, and to distinguish explicitly between persons and organizations, and between stylistic, periodical or geographical indications.

The chapter begins by discussing the elements provided for the encoding of corporate names (corpName), geographical names (geogName), period names (periodName), personal names (persName) and style names (styleName). As it is recommended to use referring strings conforming to standards and to record the names and web-accessible locations of utilized controlled vocabularies the chapter is closed with a survey of controlled vocabularies for geographical, organizational and personal names.

div.head: Overview of the namesDates module
div.p: The module described in this chapter makes available the following components:

div.head: Elements
div.p: Basic Elements and Data Structures of the namesDates module are:

div.head: corpName
div.p: Corporate names are non-personal names which refer to structured bodies of one or more persons that act as a single entity. Typical examples include associations, businesses, projects or institutions (e.g. 'the Royal College of Music' or 'the BBC'), but also racial or ethnic groupings or political factions where these are regarded as forming a single agency. Organization names typically include some type of indicator or pattern or words that help identify them as non-personal names.
Secondary name parts may be encoded in corpName sub-elements, for example: Federal Research Division, Library of Congress

CorpName elements as well as corpName sub-elements can be replanished with address-elements to note postal addresses of organizations within several addrLine-elements. German Research Foundation
Kennedyallee 40 53175 Bonn Germany

div.head: geogName
div.p: Geographical names are proper noun designations for places (e.g. Baltimore, Maryland), natural features (e.g. Black Forest) or political jurisdictions (e.g. Quartier Latin, Paris). Like other proper nouns or noun phrases used as names, they can simply be marked up with the geogName element. Baltimore, Maryland
Name sub-parts may be encoded in geogName sub-elements. For example: Baltimore, Maryland

The encoder may use these attributes in combination. For example: Baltimore, Maryland
or with regard to the example given in chapter corpName: German Research Foundation
Kennedyallee 40 53175 Bonn Germany

div.head: periodName
div.p: PeriodNames are names which describe a particular period of time, for example 'Baroque' or '3rd Style Period'. Baroque

div.head: persName
div.p: Personal names within an MEI-Doument could simply be marked up with the persName element which contains a propernoun or proper-noun phrase referring to an individual person. Personal names consist of several components. Forenames and surnames, but also other components like inherited or life-time titles of nobility, honorific or academic prefixes, military ranks or traditional descriptive phrases could not be marked up separately in MEI.

list.label: @role
list.item: Apart from the composer or originator of a musical work, there could be a lot of other persons being involved into the genesis of a musical work, like librettists, lyricists, arrangers, editors, transcripers, printers, publishers etc. The special roles of these persons could be marked up with the role attribute. For example: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

div.p: It is recommended to record personal names by using a standard for personal names, such as the Gemeinsame Normdatei (GND) or the Library of Congress Name Authorities. The name of the list as well as the web-accessible location from which a controlled value is taken may be recorded using the authority and the authURI attribute. To record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database, the dbkey attribute may be used.
The encoder may use these attributes in combination. For example: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

div.head: styleName
div.p: Music can be devided into many genres different ways. These classifications are often arbitrary and closely related styles often overlap. The label styleName describes a characteristic style of writing or performance, for example 'bebop' or 'rock-n-roll'. This element should not be confused with the periodName element (see above). bebop

div.head: Attribute Classes
div.p: No attribute classes are defined in this module.
